prior_works.title: Predicting disruptive instabilities in controlled fusion plasmas using deep learning
prior_works.authors: K. Kates-Harbeck, A. Svyatkovskiy, W. Tang
prior_works.role: Seminal deep learning for disruption prediction
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established that end-to-end deep neural networks trained on multi-diagnostic tokamak data can forecast disruptions, directly motivating the paper’s emphasis on (1) disruption prediction as a near-term, high-impact ML opportunity.

prior_works.title: APODIS: a real-time disruption predictor for JET
prior_works.authors: J. Vega, A. Murari, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated feasibility of deploying ML predictors in real-time on a major device, grounding the paper’s call for robust, operationally-relevant ML for disruption avoidance and mitigation.

prior_works.title: Trained neural network surrogate model for QuaLiKiz
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed that neural surrogates of expensive transport models can enable fast integrated simulations, directly informing the paper’s (2) simulation and dynamics modeling agenda for ML-accelerated physics.

prior_works.title: Magnetic control of tokamak plasmas through deep reinforcement learning
prior_works.authors: J. Degrave, F. Felici, et al.
prior_works.role: Deep RL for plasma magnetic control
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Proved that deep RL can synthesize plasma shape and position controllers on a real tokamak, underpinning the paper’s (4) improving controls theme and its case for learning-enabled controllers.

prior_works.title: Real-time simulations of tokamak plasmas using RAPTOR
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced fast, control-oriented transport simulations and state estimation, motivating the paper’s proposals for ML-enhanced observers, MPC, and hybrid models in plasma control.

prior_works.title: The Materials Project: A materials genome approach to accelerating materials innovation
prior_works.authors: A. Jain, S. P. Ong, G. Hautier, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provided a blueprint for large-scale data and ML accelerating materials design, directly informing the paper’s (6) enhancing materials discovery opportunity for fusion-relevant materials.

prior_works.title: OMFIT: a framework for integrated modeling and data analysis for tokamak experiments
prior_works.authors: O. Meneghini, L. L. Lao, J. M. Park, et al.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Showed how standardized data interfaces and workflows enable scalable modeling and ML, aligning with the paper’s discussion on modernizing the fusion data ecosystem to unlock new ML applications.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution is a structured agenda that pinpoints six fusion challenges where machine learning can deliver outsized impact, and it is directly scaffolded by several landmark works. For disruption prediction, Kates-Harbeck et al. (2019) established the viability of deep learning on multi-diagnostic streams to forecast disruptions, while JET’s APODIS demonstrated real-time operational deployment—together motivating the paper’s recommendation to transition from proof-of-concept predictors to robust, interpretable, and device-generalizable systems. For simulation and dynamics modeling, Citrin et al. (2017) showed that neural surrogates of turbulent transport (e.g., QuaLiKiz) can bring orders-of-magnitude speedups, supporting the paper’s call for ML-accelerated multiphysics workflows and uncertainty-aware surrogates. In control, Degrave et al. (2022) proved deep RL can control plasma shape on a real device, and Felici & Sauter’s RAPTOR provided a control-oriented modeling paradigm; these anchor the paper’s vision for hybrid ML–physics controllers, state estimators, and MPC. The agenda’s materials discovery thrust draws on the Materials Project’s demonstration that curated data infrastructures and ML pipelines can systematically accelerate materials innovation—an approach readily adapted to fusion-relevant, radiation-tolerant materials. Finally, OMFIT exemplifies the data and workflow integration the paper argues is essential: standardized schemas, accessible archives, and tooling to make fusion data ML-ready. Collectively, these works justify the paper’s claim that fusion is primed for impactful ML across prediction, modeling, inference, control, experimental design, and materials.
